question_text: How do heat and mass transfer principles govern the pyrolysis of microalgal biomass into bio-oil, and what is the role of flash pyrolysis in maximizing conversion efficiency? Explain the relationship between bio-oil water content and its combustion properties, including effects on viscosity, fluidity, heating value, and flame temperature.
standard_answer: Pyrolysis of microalgal biomass involves thermal decomposition in an inert atmosphere, where heat transfer drives the thermal degradation of biomass components into volatile compounds. Mass transfer governs the movement of these volatiles away from the reaction zone. Flash pyrolysis, characterized by rapid heating rates, minimizes secondary reactions by quickly removing vapors from the hot zone, achieving up to 80% conversion efficiency from biomass to bio-oil. The high water content in bio-oil significantly impacts combustion properties: it reduces viscosity and enhances fluidity, which improves atomization during combustion. However, this high water content simultaneously reduces the heating value and lowers flame temperature, requiring careful optimization for practical fuel applications. These thermal and transport phenomena are critical in designing efficient pyrolysis reactors for microalgal biofuel production.
